brief_description:
To assess the effects of the impairments in innate immunity identified in the study titled Delineate innate immune responses in populations at risk (the elderly and the immunosuppressed) that are different from the general population on the efficiency of the response to agents of Bioterrorism, using WN virus infection and influenza vaccination as models.

Will also assess these responses directly from patients who had WN virus infection or the influenza vaccine. Will elucidate mechanisms mediating innate immune responses to viral infection using murine models.
brief_title: Determine whether differences in TLR-responsiveness alter susceptibility to Biodefense priority pathogens using WN virus as a paradigm or responsiveness to vaccination using influenza as a model shared to Semi-Public Workspace (SPW) Project
condition_studied: West Nile Virus, immune response, aging, infectious diseases
description:
The Study's goal is to quantify the innate immune response of macrophages from the three populations identified in the study titled 'Delineate innate immune responses in populations at risk (the elderly and the immunosuppressed) that are different from the general population', to agents of Biodefense, using West Nile virus infection and influenza vaccination as models.

In addition, by recruiting patients who have had West Nile virus infection or received influenza vaccine, we will assess the efficiency of immune responses to these potential agents of bioterrorism.
endpoints:
1. Effects of aging and immunosuppression on the efficiency of activation of monocytes and DCs by influenza vaccine.
  2. Employ standard hemagglutination inhibition assays to determine responsiveness to influenza vaccine.
  3. WN viral titers will be determined by ELISA on serum samples.
  4. Isolated cells will be stimulated with WN virus in vitro and elaboration of inflammatory cytokines (including MIF), and TLR expression will be quantified.
hypothesis: Innate immune responses are weak in the elderly and the immunocompromised and may be influenced by polymorphisms in certain TLRs and a prototype TLR-dependent cytokine, macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF).
objectives: To address the possibility that alterations in TLR function may correlate with vaccine responsiveness the study assess TLR signaling in responsive and non-responsive older individuals immunized with influenza vaccine.
official_title: Determine whether differences in TLR-responsiveness alter susceptibility to Biodefense priority pathogens using WN virus as a paradigm or responsiveness to vaccination using influenza as a model shared to Semi-Public Workspace (SPW) Project
